Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-China Planning Visit: Establishing Collaborations on Electronic and Optoelectronic Nanomaterial Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to support a planning visit to the Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics in Wuhan, China. Participants in the trip will include Professor Wenzhi Li, one graduate student, and one undergraduate. The purpose of the trip is to develop a collaboration in research and education on synthesis and applications of carbon nanotubes and semiconducting nanowires in optoelectronic devices. The expertise of the Chinese collaborators in optoelectronics complements that of the PI in synthesis of novel nanomaterials.

In promoting research collaboration among the participants, this planning visit will develop new materials and more effective devices for important applications, such as advanced sensors and solar cells. The participation of the students in this international program will broaden their personal and professional perspectives. The PI plans to involve undergraduate students from underrepresented populations, and this experience should stimulate them to continue in a scientific career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and two students at Florida International University have visited the Chinese research team at Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics (WNLO) in China. The outcomes from the two visits are summarized below.

On July 4-15, 2011, the PI (Dr. Wenzhi Li) and two Florida International University students (Ms. Rocio Gonzalez and Mr. Guillermo Matranca) visited WNLO. The foreign collaborators are Professor Yihua Gao and his research team at WNLO. During this planning visit, the FIU team has conducted the following activities. (1) With the help of Professor Gao, the FIU team visited several laboratories or research groups at WNLO, such as the Organic Optoelectronics group, the Nanomaterial and Nano Optoelectronics group,
the Michael Gratzel Center for Mesoscopic Solar Cells, the Micro/Nano
Fabrication Facility for Optoelectronics, etc. The FIU team learned about the
current research projects undertaken by the WNLO scientists and students and the research infrastructure needed for advanced research. During the lab
visits, U.S. and Chinese students had interactive conversations on many
forefront research topics. (2) The FIU team and Professor Gao’s group organized joint research seminars in which several research presentations were given by the PI and the U.S. and Chinese graduate students. The students from the U.S. team and the Chinese team exchanged their research ideas and research experience. (3) The PI and Professor Gao discussed possible collaborative research projects and decided to work together on the electronic and optoelectronic properties of carbon nanotubes and related materials. The planning visit enabled the U.S. PI to develop a mutually beneficial collaboration with his Chinese partner on the research of electronic and optoelectronic materials.

On July 30 - August 3, 2012, the PI (Dr. Wenzhi Li) revisited WNLO. The foreign collaborators are Professor Yihua Gao and his research team at WNLO. The activities conducted during the trip include the following. (1) The PI visited the Chinese team at WNLO and had several discussions on research projects currently undertaken in the US and Chinese groups. (2) The PI and Dr. Gao and Dr. Gao's graduate students discussed the research results about the negative photoconductivity of tin dioxide-multiwall carbon nanotube nanostructures, a collaborative research project between the U.S.
group and Chinese group established in the first visit. A draft paper about the
research results is under development. (3) The PI and Dr. Gao agreed to expand their collaborative research to solar cells in which carbon nanotube thin films and composites will be used as photo anodes and counter electrodes.

Mr. Guillermo Matranca, a graduate student at Florida International University, who visited the WNLO in 2011, has successfully defended his thesis and graduated with a mater degree in physics in 2012. Ms. Rocio Gonzalez, a FIU undergraduate student, who visited the WNLO 2011, was inspired by the research visit and participated actively in research in the PI’s lab at FIU in the spring and summer of 2012 and gained hands-on research experience.
